title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Tugging on their fur caps, thetwo thieves seized the box by the handles, turned down thelight, and picked their way to the door, followed by Clunie andthe boy.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Picking his way after the boy through piles of broken chairs,rotten sofas with the stuffing hanging out, torn carpets inheaps, legless tables, and decayed bedsteads, Clunie at lastcame upon a snug recess at the back, where there was a fire, abed, a table covered with a smoking meal, and seated thereattwo of the most repulsive-looking ruffians that he had everclapped eyes on.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: "Ye're to come in; Toby '11 see ye himsei'," whispered theboy; and in another moment Clunie was drawn in, and thedoor shut and locked behind him.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: This hasty scrawl, and a shilling along with it, Clunie thrustinto the hand of a rather stupid Irishwoman, who happened tocome down the stair upon some errand of her own, andimplored her to run up to the Police Office on a matter of lifeand death.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: " Robert Clunie, Medical Student."

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Upon thispoint, however, Clunie gave himself no time to think, for themoment he was certain he was alone and unobserved, hewhipped out his pocket-book, tore out a leaf, and scribbleddown the following urgent message—

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Clunie peered out sharply as the door of the outhouse was opened, but he could make out nothing but thatthe place seemed stored to the very door with old and brokenfurniture, which was either too worthless to sell, or was keptthere merely as a blind to what went on behind.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Clunie said nothing, but plunged in, and soon found himself in a back-yard, facing a kind of broker's store-room, andclose to the last common stair in the entry.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Had I been in Clunie's place,knowing Toby as I did, I candidly confess I would have let thebox go; but the student was ignorant, and thought himselfclever—a state of things fraught with danger at the best.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: The lad swallowed his glass of beer and lighted his pipe, whileClunie got the required change, and then both slowly ascendedto the street.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: The trunk was left on the street, Clunie only onceglancing at it, and saying dubiously—" But will it be safe there till we come out again ? ""Safe!—ay, as safe as oorsel's," was the emphatic reply, andthen the two vanished down the steps.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Clunie had no prideabout him, but took the handle of his trunk as coolly up theBridge as if porterage had been his every-day occupation; butby the time Hunter Square was reached, his arms were both sostrained and sore with the great weight that he instantly votedthat they take a rest; and as he wanted change of half-a-sovereign to pay the lad, he invited him down to a tavern tohave a glass of beer—an offer which was accepted with greatalacrity.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Clunie, not beingblessed with an overplus of money, resolved fo effect theremoval as economically as possible; and so, having packed uphis few books, medical instruments, and valuables, in an ironbound trunk, and fastened a writing-desk and some other strayarticles on the top, he engaged a hungry-looking lad off the

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: One fine evening in spring, Robert Clunie, a medical student,residing in St James' Square, took it into his head that thelocality was not the most reputable in the world, and resolvedto shift to a lodging in the south side.
